item.description:
After their latest journey through time, the Odynauts have landed in the Stone Age. In this world, they are confronted with cavemen who revere fire above all else. Because not all cavemen have yet discovered how to make fire, some try to steal it from the others. The Odynauts see a challenging game in all of this, but being their usual selves think it would be more fun to put out an opponent's fire rather than to steal it. Can you navigate safely through enemy caves? Can your cavemen outwit their stronger opponents or overpower their weaker ones? Can you be the first to put out an opponent's fire?

Cavemen Playing With Fire is a strategic two-player card game. The goal is to be the first player to put out one of her opponent's three fires, which in game terms means taking one of the opponent's three fire cards.

To play the game, each player receives an identical deck of 25 cave, fire, and caveman cards. Players use the cave cards to create a playing field on the table with three fire cards for each player at each end. In turns, players place cards and take action. They walk and fight among their own caves and those of the enemy to try to reach one of the enemy's fire cards. The cavemen cards are ranked, and some have special abilities. Lost cards can return to the drawing deck, but to do so a player must lose certain cards first. Losing these is tricky, though.

item.description:
The Odynauts are a competitive race of aliens that prosper from the feeling that winning brings them. The one place on Earth where lady luck truly smiles at you is the casino. The Odynauts decided to take the gamble and spread out to the foremost gambling cities on our planet, from Macau to Monte Carlo and from Las Vegas to Amsterdam. They turned the casinos upside down and won at every game the casinos have on offer. Slot machines were cleaned out and poker tournaments were won. The casino bosses were not amused and quickly banned the Odynauts from their casinos. To still their voracious appetite for winning, the Odynauts have made their own casino game. Casino chips are bitten into pieces and slot machines are stolen. All these well-known items from the casino form the basis of new and unique game: Chipleader. The Odynauts challenge you. Are you brave enough to accept their challenge? Are you a smart gambler and do you have the strategic insight to score the most points in putting casino chips back together? Can you protect your chips from your opponents' attacks?

Chipleader is card game for two to four players. The goal is to collect as many points as you can with strategic gambling and by making casino chips before four different casinos have been visited. Players have to protect their casino chips against their opponents' attacks in an effort to become Chipleader.

Casino chips are made with chip fragment cards of different colors and values. Every chip fragment card has a quarter of a chip depicted on it. Four chip fragment cards can form a casino chip and only when a player has formed such a chip can she place those cards on the table. The value of a complete casino chip placed on the table can increase or decrease with the use of Odynaut face cards. By playing these cards, a player's opponents can even entirely eliminate the value of one of her chips.

To obtain chip fragment and Odynaut face cards, a player has to make sets with five types of "gamble-suit" cards. Five suit cards are randomly placed face up alongside each other on the table. This row of cards is called the "gambling row". Each player also receives three suit cards at the beginning of the game. A set is created whenever three, four or five suit cards of the same type are aligned in the gambling row.

name.value: Star Fleet Marines: Module I – Assault

item.description:
From the publishers website and press release:

This is the first entirely new game system from ADB, Inc., in years. It brings infantry combat in the Star Fleet Universe to life in a way that allows ground battles to be fought simultaneously with the space battles portrayed by Star Fleet Battles, Federation Commander, Starmada, or A Call to Arms SF.

Over 500 unit counters portray squads of five Marines, snipers, engineers, commandos, and heavy weapons; or individual tanks and vehicles; or special game markers.

The very simple “shoot then move” system reflects the savage horror of war at bayonet point. Fast interaction is created by rules for opportunity fire and defensive snapshots, so both players are constantly acting, reacting, planning, and making hard decisions. Do you fire at those Klingon troops attacking your right flank — or hold the fire of your weapons for the main attack that has yet to appear (and might never)?

The full-color highly artistic map portrays the terrain on a typical planet far, far away, but rules allow you to designate the colored areas as crops, forest, swamps, marshes, or any of a dozen other types of alien landscape. The map even includes an active volcano and a river of lava!

Each counter is a group of five Marines (i.e., a "Boarding Party" from SFB or a "Marine squad" from FC, facilitating interactions) or a single vehicle (tank, ground combat vehicle, shuttle, or whatever). Each hex is 100 meters. While you can stack a lot of units in one hex (more infantry than vehicles, but still a lot), only a few can fire out of that hex in each direction.

The game system is one of player turns. On your turn, each of your units can either shoot or move, not both. Shooting comes first (after which the unit is turned upside down so that you remember not to move it), then movement, then you turn all of your upside down units right side up. When you shoot at an enemy unit, you cross-index the kind of unit that is shooting with the kind of unit being shot at, adjust this for any terrain that provides protection, and roll one die. The enemy unit might be destroyed, stunned (turned upside down so it won't be able to shoot or move on its next turn), or unharmed.

The first game module, SFM: Assault!, includes Marines, other infantry (commando, heavy weapons, engineers, Prime Teams, militia), and vehicles (tanks, trucks, engineer vehicles, command vehicles, and various light-armored troop carriers).

Units will be able to dig in, call for regular artillery or transporter artillery, do assault landings with shuttles or transporters, do close assaults, use opportunity fire to shoot during the enemy turn, and conduct air strikes with fighters or gunboats.

item.description:
GLADIUS

Gladius is a 2-4 player card game illustrated by Gonzo Bríos.

In GLADIUS the players take on the role of a lanista. Your goal is to select the best gladiators in your ludus and organize the best fights in the amphitheater. The player that organizes the best fights wins the game.

The players use cards from your hand to steal cards from the board of equal or lesser value. With those cards players create fights between distinct gladiators and place in front of them. The score of the fight is determined by the difference between the values â€‹â€‹of the gladiators. The player with the highest score in his fights wins the game.

The game components are:
A deck of 52 cards, 48 gladiators cards and 4 christians cards.

				
					=======================

GLADIUS

Gladius es un juego de cartas para 2-4 jugadores ilustrado por Gonzo Bríos.

En GLADIUS adoptas el rol de un lanista. Tu objetivo es seleccionar los mejores gladiadores de tu ludus y organizar los mejores combates en el anfiteatro. Aquel lanista que organice los mejores combates ganará el favor del César.

En GLADIUS los jugadores organizan combates utilizando cartas de su mano para robar cartas de la mesa de igual o menor valor. Con esas cartas robadas forman combates de gladiadores distintos que colocan frente a ellos. La puntuación de los combates está determinada por la diferencia entre los valores de los gladiadores que luchan. El jugador que obtenga la mayor puntuación en sus combates gana el juego.

Los componentes del juego son:
Un mazo de 52 cartas, 48 cartas de gladiadores y 4 cartas de cristianos.

item.description:
Arkham Madhouse is a card-game for 2-4 players illustrated by Pedro Belushi.

The Arkham asylums have opened their doors and their residents have escaped. They roam the city like lost souls. Your job is to bring them to the place from which they never should have left. Drive your ambulance through the streets of Arkham and find those crazy men.

And if you think this is a lame excuse to honor H. P. Lovecraft... Cthulhu will drive you mad!

On the table there is a map of Arkham formed by ten cards. The players move on the map of Arkham using the action cards. Players collect mad men cards when his pawn stays on a map card that matches the color of mad men card. Mad men cards have different values. At the end of the game the player that gets the highest score using these mad men cards is the winner.


Los manicomios de Arkham han abierto sus puertas y los residentes han escapado. Vagan por la ciudad como almas en pena. Tu trabajo es lograr que vuelvan al lugar del que nunca deberían haber salido. Conduce tu ambulancia por las calles de Akham y devuelve a los perturbados a su manicomio. Y si crees que esto es una burda excusa para homenajear a H. P. Lovecraft, que Cthulhu te arrebate la cordura para siempre.

Sobre la mesa se forma un mapa de Arkham con diez cartas. Los jugadores recorren Arkham moviendo su peón utilizando las cartas de acción. Los jugadores recogen cartas de locos cuando coincide el color de la carta de loco y de la carta de mapa sobre la que está su peón. Las cartas de loco tienen distinta puntuación. Al final del juego aquel que obtenga la máxima puntuación con las cartas de loco es el ganador.

item.description:
Caperucita is a card game for children.

Beware the wolf! In Caperucita the players run the forest path to grandmother's house and collect as many flowers as they can while they avoid the wolf.

The aim of Caperucita is to collect as many flowers while avoiding you catch the wolf. You must play your cards with the ability to earn points for each pair of flowers formed and ensure that the wolf catch the other players. The game ends when the deck runs out of flowers or when the wolf has caught all the players less
to one.

				
					====================

Caperucita es un juego de cartas para niños.

¡Cuidado con el lobo! En Caperucita los jugadores recorren el
camino del bosque hacia la casa de la abuelita y recogen el mayor número de flores mientras evitan que el lobo los atrape.

El objetivo de Caperucita es recoger el mayor número de flores al tiempo que evitas que te atrape el lobo. Debes jugar tus cartas con habilidad para obtener puntos por cada pareja de flores formada y procurar que el lobo atrape a los otros jugadores. El juego termina cuando se acaba el mazo de flores o cuando el lobo ha atrapado a todos los jugadores menos
a uno.

item.description:
"Aegean Fleet is a contemporary game of naval warfare taking place in Aegean Sea.
Time Scale : 
- 8 hours per turn
- 80 km per hex.

The players maneuver war ships, submarines, aircrafts, amphibious war ships and cargos on a map covering.

The game reuse rules from Victory Games Fleet series, but includes new weapons as missiles, grond launched ballistic missiles, SAM, cruise missiles
There are also new rules regarding submarines, Aegis ships, anti-missile defence systems, long range air-to-air missile,

The game can be linked with Arab-Israel Fleet and Black Sea Expansion

"Iron Lady’s Fleet” is a game of naval warfare taking place in South-Atlantic during the Falklands Wars in 1982.
Time Scale : 
- 8 hours per turn
- 80 km per hex.

The players maneuver war ships, submarines, aircrafts, amphibious war ships and cargos on a map covering.

The game reuse rules from Victory Games Fleet series, but includes new weapons as missiles, ground launched ballistic missiles, SAM, cruise missiles
There are also new rules regarding submarines, Aegis ships, anti-missile defence systems, long range air-to-air missile,

More Information:

The game includes 5 scénarios, from very simple to more complex ones :
1/ Bluff Cove Black Death
2/ Lost Cruiser
3/ Strike San Carlos
4/ Like Churchill's her fought
5/ Galtieri's Backhand Blow

This is a simple game designed to teach children the difference between right and left.

The game is played by rolling a die and moving one of two pieces on a board, trying to collect stamps from a stamp pad on a sheet.

There are two shared pieces: Lisa the cat, who always travels to the left (clockwise); and Rex the dog, who always travels to the right (counter-clockwise). There are corresponding stamps for each animal.

There is a circular track on the board with three types of space: dog, cat, and "restless bear." Players roll a die that moves either Lisa or Rex 1 to 3 spaces, being sure to announce which direction they are going ("Lisa is moving to the left.").

If the moving animal lands on its own type of space, the player collects a stamp of that animal on their sheet. Four stamps of any one animal (either Lisa or Rex) wins.

If the animal lands on the opposite animal space, nothing happens.

If the animal lands on a restless bear space, the player may still collect a stamp, but only if they do something with the correct side of the body. For example, if Lisa lands on a bear space, a player might say "Lisa is waving her left paw."

If a player lands on the other animal, they get a stamp from both; if this is on a restless bear space, however, they must first do something with both sides of their body.

Those were the days! You may well remember clogs or tight hot pants. Then you come up with a playful journey through the decade. You can expect statements about events, Zeitgeist, TV, Celebrities and Stars. For each statement, you get 3 answers. Use your memory and remember the headlines at the time or just type. Become an expert 70s?

Player with the most correct answers wins the game.

Quiz of the Decade series from Noris publisher attributes the players in the 90s. Each participant tries to get through right answer as many questions of quiz cards. Who has the most cards at the end in his possession wins the game.

The quiz cards are shuffled and placed in a pile in the middle of the table. There are six categories: 1) History & Politics, 2) literature and film, 3) Sports & Games, 4) Technology & Cars, 5) music and 6) Misc. 
The active player rolls the dice and one player takes the bottom card from the pile and reads the corresponding question. Now the player must choose one of four answer choices, because only one of the answers is correct.

Quiz of the Decade series from Noris publisher attributes the players in the 80s. Each participant tries to get through right answer as many questions of quiz cards. Who has the most cards at the end in his possession wins the game.

The quiz cards are shuffled and placed in a pile in the middle of the table. There are six categories: 1) History & Politics, 2) literature and film, 3) Sports & Games, 4) Technology & Cars, 5) music and 6) Misc. 
The active player rolls the dice and one player takes the bottom card from the pile and reads the corresponding question. Now the player must choose one of four answer choices, because only one of the answers is correct.

Quiz of the Decade series from Noris publisher attributes the players in the 60s. Each participant tries to get through right answer as many questions of quiz cards. Who has the most cards at the end in his possession wins the game.

The quiz cards are shuffled and placed in a pile in the middle of the table. There are six categories: 1) History & Politics, 2) literature and film, 3) Sports & Games, 4) Technology & Cars, 5) music and 6) Misc. 
The active player rolls the dice and one player takes the bottom card from the pile and reads the corresponding question. Now the player must choose one of four answer choices, because only one of the answers is correct.

Quiz of the Decade series from Noris publisher attributes the players in the 50s. Each participant tries to get through right answer as many questions of quiz cards. Who has the most cards at the end in his possession wins the game.

The quiz cards are shuffled and placed in a pile in the middle of the table. There are six categories: 1) History & Politics, 2) literature and film, 3) Sports & Games, 4) Technology & Cars, 5) music and 6) Misc. 
The active player rolls the dice and one player takes the bottom card from the pile and reads the corresponding question. Now the player must choose one of four answer choices, because only one of the answers is correct.

Quiz of the Decade series from Noris publisher attributes the players in the 70s. Each participant tries to get through right answer as many questions of quiz cards. Who has the most cards at the end in his possession wins the game.

The quiz cards are shuffled and placed in a pile in the middle of the table. There are six categories: 1) History & Politics, 2) literature and film, 3) Sports & Games, 4) Technology & Cars, 5) music and 6) Misc. 
The active player rolls the dice and one player takes the bottom card from the pile and reads the corresponding question. Now the player must choose one of four answer choices, because only one of the answers is correct.

The players alternate placing a sector former (i.e. wall) in a vertical or horizontal slot on the board. Following placement, the player inserts one of their colored tiles into all squared sectors (i.e. a square surrounded by four sectors) and receives points for each tile placed.

Several Supergrid variations exist. Please see the attached files for the complete set of game rules.

Fantail Golf is a didactic board game,very fun and to play with the family, where participants play simulating the path of the Golf field with 9 or 18 holes. Each participant has his personal card, hole by hole, and enter your information in the General Board Positions.
Golfers in turn, first, throw the four-sided dice to know under what weather conditions play a certain number of holes. These weather conditions that are four: optimal, good, changing and adverse, have influence on the chances of holing the hole in fewer strokes. Then, each golfer rolls the twelve-sided dice to play the hole to be played. According to the number thrown every golfer will place your piece on the Golf field (board) into the fairway, rough, hazard, bunker or the green. These possibilities as well as the tees and the holes are indicated on the Golf field.
The object of the game is to finish the number of holes agreed with the least amount of strokes taken.

In Foosball players are players of two football teams and their goal is to win the game. This game is inspired by the classic foosball.

Foosball is a game for 8-22 players, aged eight years, with a variable playing time depending on what players want. It's a typical convention game for a large number of players that have a long table to sit comfortably face to face.

In each team one player will be the goalkeeper, another player will be the striker and the others will be field players. The game is divided into rounds, which end when a team scores a goal. Each round begins with a goal kick. Goalkeeper places the ball in front of him and then the goalkeeper rolls ball (rolls die). When player rolls the ball, any other player of the same team can claim the ball and the opposing team can attempt to steal the ball. If the player that has received the ball is a striker, he can shot at goal. The team that has received fewer goals is the winner


En Futbolín los jugadores forman parte de dos equipos de fútbol que se enfrentan en un partido, y su objetivo es
ganar dicho partido. Este juego está inspirado en el clásico futbolín.

Futbolín es un juego para 8-22 jugadores, mayores de ocho años, con una duración variable determinada en función de lo que los jugadores deseen. Es un típico juego de convención para un número alto de jugadores que deben disponer de una mesa larga para sentarse cómodamente frente a frente.

En cada equipo un jugador será el portero, otro el delantero y el resto jugadores de campo. El juego se divide en rondas, que concluyen cuando un equipo marca gol. En cada ronda el juego comienza con un saque de puerta. Le entregamos el dado que hace de balón al portero, que comienza el juego lanzando el dado. Una vez el dado se ha lanzado, cualquier compañero del jugador que ha lanzado puede reclamarlo, y cualquier contrario entre ambos jugadores puede robarlo. El delantero, cuando recibe el balón, puede lanzar a puerta. Gana el equipo que logra más goles.

item.description:
The goal of the game is to get the most points by answering questions about blondes

The active player rolls the dice and takes a card from the deck, asking question according die-roll. He can try to explain with words (he can't use words from the answer), or by drawing gestures for other players to get close to the answer.

Player who finds the correct answer, scores 2 points and moves accordingly on the game board. The active player scores 1 point.

The game ends if somebody reaches to finish on the game board.
He is the winner.

What profession learned Erich Honecker? Which product has been sold under the brand name "Erika"?
These and similar questions must be answered in this game. 
For each question, you get 3 answers. Answer correctly and move forward with character on the game board. 
Player who finishes first is the winner.

Motor Race game from Wolverine Supply dated 1910. Players spin a spinner and go around the track. Penalties are listed on spaces on the board. There is even a space for Tire Trouble with its own spinner to tell how many turns you lose while your tires are being fixed. You must finish the game by exact count in order to win.

name.value: Das Quiz rund um den Euro

item.description:
The game board has four fields on each edge, each of these fields has a six question cards. The answers are on the back of each card. Now a number of dice-chips (from one to six) are chosen. This specifies the question to be answered in this round on the cards. Each player now receives chips with various values â€‹â€‹of 5€ to 500€ and a joker. 
On his turn player bets depending on whether he knows the answer, or rather has to guess, he now sets up a low-or high-order chip and then responds. If the answer is wrong, the chip remains on the field. If it was correct he wins double chips.

Player with the most chips (€) at the end of the game wins.

Marbles? merges the exciting aspects of a party game with one-on-one challenges both observed and judged by all other players, the Peanut Gallery. Many of the challenges are reminiscent of familiar games. Others are very unique and designed specifically for the roles of Challenger, Opponent and Peanut Gallery. Marble-like gems are the currency. Players must use their intellectual marbles to win challenges and also strategically pose challenges that are to their greatest advantage. Highly dimensional, there are multiple perspectives of strategy.

Players take turns being the Challenger and can select any player not previously an Opponent in the same round. "Teaser" cards indicate Opponent availability. Opponent cards change the dynamics of the challenge. Peanut Gallery cards permit side wagers, further expanding the dimensions of how the game is played.

All challenges are performed in (2) minutes or less. Challenger cards detail a wide variety of tasks across (7) categories:
1) Consensus - The Peanut Gallery is polled to derive a count that the opponent must accurately predict. Some are factual events like visiting an ATM within the last 24 hours while others are preferences such as: Cat or Dog, Chocolate or Vanilla, Paper or Plastic…
2) Dice - Challenger cards in this category require a specified outcome from the roll of dice. Luck over skill, the tasks vary as defined for each challenge.
3) Domino – To win, the Opponent must also hold a Challenger card in this category having a Domino number that matches one of the two numbers presented by the Challenger.
4) Performance – Opponent must skillfully complete the challenge. Examples include telling a joke that invokes laughter and an impersonation in which the Peanut Gallery must correctly guess.
5) Physical – Another skill category, the Opponent must successfully complete a task involving an activity like Origami (paper folding) or Roshambo (Rock-Paper-Scissors). When the results are subjective, the Peanut Gallery judges the task.
6) Playing Cards – A single hand of a common card game is played, such as Blackjack or Draw Poker. Every Challenger card in this category fully defines the task and specifies the requirements necessary to win.
7) Starter – Cards in this category quickly establish the winner, simply with who holds the highest number.

The objective is simple. Take turns matching a Challenger card in hand with an opponent anticipated least likely to successfully complete the task. Opponents set the wager, either (1) or (2) marbles, upon the Challenger announcing the category. Should the Opponent fail the task, the Challenger wins the wager. Otherwise, the Opponent collects the wager. Number of players determines the number of rounds. At game end after the final showdown (in case of a tie, if necessary), the player with the most marbles reigns supreme.

Not at all the game of marbles everyone played as a child, this version is all grown up but still retains the youthful retro spirit.
"Wanna play Marbles?"

180 Marbles? Cards, 4 Color-Coded Types, 7 Challenger Categories

Objective:
be the first climbing up the board to the top by knowing the correct answers.
A quiz game for people who just turned 50 and want to test their knowledge about trendy things from those times.

Whoever's guess is correct advances on the scoring board faster than other players.
More fun is achieved by reaching marked/coloured fields on the board; allowed ways of explaining are significantly reduced;

Content:

 1 game board
 6 characters
 1 dice
 104 cards with over 1200 terms
 6 response cards
 1 Hourglass
 1 set of instructions

Here the women are playing against the men, and vice versa. Do you know how many cylinders a Porsche 911 has? Or is the material from which the best nail file? These and similar questions must be answered here. Depending on the game type questions are asked of others and / or the same sex. The players love one estimate, if the question can be answered correctly or not. Who know a lot or can bluff well is rapidly advancing on the board and win this battle of the sexes - at least temporarily!

The game has been updated to version 3! It's a complete revamp and change from version 2 for faster and more strategic gameplay.

A fast paced card game featuring two opponents slugging it out in each other's faces. Very easy to learn, but the strategy lies in reading your opponent and strategizing your own moves. Do you go all out and attack heavily from the start? Or do you lean back and wait for your opponent to strike first?

How to Play
1. Players are dealt 9 cards
2. Players take turns playing a valid card from their hand. A valid card is one that is equal to or higher than the current card in play. If there isn't a card in play, the player may play any card.
3. After the player plays a valid card it is the next player's turn.

How to Win
Discard your entire hand first to win.

Passing / Drawing a Card
If a player is not able to play a card, they must draw a card. The player's turn is now over. A player may also choose to draw a card even if they have a valid card to play.

Block
A player can BLOCK once per game. A BLOCK causes both players to draw a card. The player's turn is now over.

Shadow Fist / Playing Pairs
A player may start to play pairs if the pair they wish to play is the same as the current card in play. Subsequent plays must be pairs until a player passes, blocks, or wins.

The 1 Card
The 1 card may be played after the 10 card.

Business hours in English allows the player to get into the business manager role, reflecting the business processes.

The object of the game is to be the first player to get the most traditional customer base, or the highest market share.

In his turn player can generete experience of his company by searching customers or buy and sale products. 
When they have loyal customer, when products are offered for sale, they can make even the highest prices.
Two players can at any time join forces in order to reduce market competition and displace opponents. In this case, players combine business with all their resources: both players money, privileges, raw materials and traditional customer base, but the experience can not be combined.

Word Frolic! Village Idiom I is an educational card game for ages 12 and up. It teaches players 52 different English-language idioms, and provides a well-researched definition and origin for each one.

Players take turns drawing cards and reading them aloud to the other players; the goal of each round is to fill in the blank with the proper English-language idiom. The correct answer will create a terrible pun, and earn the player 2 points. There are bonus questions worth 1 point apiece, and optional conversation starters related to the card's content. The first player to 10 points wins the game.

name.value: Los Charros Contrabandistas, Juego de Dados

item.description:
This was a really old 'Roll and Move' boardgame, the estimated date of publication is somewhere between 1890 and 1913.

The original print is kept at the Library of Congress Prints and Photographs Division Washington, D.C.

name.value: Siebzehn: The Race of All Races

item.description:
Siebzehn, the number 17 in the German language, is the ultimate competition – The Race of All Races. Nine different races of mythical creatures compete for supremacy. Each mythical race is represented by a team consisting of six numbered pieces. Two to nine players control the teams, which maneuver around the board in a counterclockwise fashion. The rules of Siebzehn are simple, but the continuous discovery of new strategies amidst the constantly evolving environment is complex, captivating and magical.

Each team proceeds such that a higher number piece can never pass a lower number piece, and the number 1 piece advances only if no other team pieces can move. Pieces move forward and diagonally in the straightaways and forward only in the turns. The object of the game is to eliminate other races and control the one race that eventually conquers all. Players eliminate opponents from the board by one of three methods:


 Circumnavigate the board and pass the highest number piece of one or more opponents with the 1 piece of one of your teams. This is known as a cataclysm and some teams will be eliminated or altered.
 Pass an opponent's 1 piece with the highest numbered piece of one of your teams. In other words, one team passes an opponent's entire team. The team that is passed is eliminated.
 Control the most advanced 1 piece in games that reach the end of the 17th cycle, known as the siebzehn cycle.


The concept of a race around a large track is central to the essence of Siebzehn, but the game is not a model of any known race. Several racing games involve familiar competitors such as horses, chariots or cars – then there is Siebzehn, an imaginary mystical race in which the competitors are famed creatures of myth and legend. As the teams travel around the board, they must persevere through careful movement and placement, calculated blocking of their own and opponent pieces, opponent blocking effects and injuries, dice probability considerations and consequences, and new unexpected ways of seeing the board.

For an inspiring and exciting gaming experience, discover the land far beyond the familiar and influence the fates of mythical creatures in Siebzehn: The Race of All Races!

name.value: Perfect Word: A Word Dice Game

item.description:
Unlike other word games, the objective of Perfect Word is to derive the single word that best matches (4) types of criteria. Roll (12) dice, draw one Perfect Word card and start the 2-minute timer. Use as many point letters as possible, including non-point letters as needed. Perfect Word cards permit one helpful exception, such as unlimited license to use the letter "P".

Word games are more fun when there is a challenging twist. The longest words are not necessarily the Perfect Word. One point is deducted for every syllable. If the required letters are available, "squirreled" is a Perfect Word. It contains (10) letters but only has (1) syllable.

Game description from the publisher:

In the mythical land of Aztlán, four tribes strive to survive and prosper under the scrutiny of the gods themselves. Peaceful coexistence brings wealth and prosperity to all, but the fearsome Aztec gods favor those who are mighty in war and bring to them their subdued enemies as cruel offerings...

Only one of the four tribes will be granted the right to stay in this blessed land when the Time of Exile comes at the end of the Fifth Age of the Sun. Guide your tribe to build the mightiest empire through the Five Ages, win the favor of the gods, and become the greatest ruler in the land of Aztlàn.

Aztlán can be played by three or four players (or two players with the "Aztec Gods" variant). In a multi-player game, each player guides one of the four tribes. A game is divided into five stages, called ages; at the beginning of each age, each player secretly chooses one of his power cards, and then one at a time places a certain number of his tribe pawns in one of the territories on the game board, which is divided into five different types of territory: deserts, terraced fields, jungles, mountains/volcanoes, and cities. The power card chosen for the age indicates the strength of that player's tribe and identifies one type of territory (of the five different types). The greater the domains of that player, and the greater the number of territories of that type included within them, the higher the victory point score.

If a territory is disputed by several players, the strongest tribe may defeat the weaker ones – but war is not the only path to victory and peaceful coexistence with the other tribes sometimes brings greater rewards. At the end of the fifth age, the player who scores the most victory points wins. His tribe rules Aztlán, while the time of Exile befalls his opponents!

item.description:
Absorb your enemy, but don't get eaten by a Grue. An abstract strategy game for Looney pyramids of capture and maneuver.

From the Icehousegames.org background:
"Battles on the savage gleeb homeworld are fought in deadly arenas. Two groups of gleebs enter, each aiming to absorb the enemy before meeting that grisly fate themselves. Further adding to the excitement are three ravenous grues who have their own plan for the gleebs..."

Each player takes 2 colors of pyramids, while the black pyramids represent Grues. On their turn, players move one of their pyramids onto a pyramid of a different color, and then must move a black pyramid, potentially immobilizing or removing pyramids from the game, even their own.

The player who controls the most pips worth of pyramids at the end of the game wins.

Requires a 4x4 playing board and 1 Treehouse stash:
3 blue pyramids in small, medium, and large
3 red pyramids in small, medium, and large
3 yellow pyramids in small, medium, and large
3 green pyramids in small, medium, and large
3 black pyramids in small, medium, and large
for a total of 15 pyramids.

item.description:
You can play Battle of the Sexes 2 in two variants, either as a team game, "women against men" or as individual players' every man for himself.

There are fewer chips than first version of the game.

In his turn the team roll the dice what determines the question to be asked. There are five questions and their answers on each card. If "6" is rolled the random question is chosen.
They reads out a question that must now discuss the other team, offered possible answers which could well be the correct or may be bluff. Other team must answer correctly to move their pawn accordinglyon the game board.
Team who finish first is the winner.

item.description:
In this game players use the four basic arithmetic operations. The aim of the game is, with at least three of the dice to calculate the numbers on the previously required results from the drawn cards.

The card is drawn the dice are rolled and the quickest player socres a point.

This is an operational level game covering the France Campaign, May - October 1940. Units are primarily divisions, with air formations also provided. There are 1,152 die-cut units representing French, British, Belgian, Dutch, German and Italian forces. The 32" x 22" inch map runs from the North Sea to the Mediterranean Seas. The War in France & Flanders was to be part of larger series of games called Crusade in Europe, which never appeared.

The sequence of play is I-Go-You-Go. There are detailed rules covering air operations; alternatively, players can use a simplified set of abstract air rules. Victory is determined by points awarded for losses, and for the date of any French surrender.

This is a new fun innovative board game that educates players about business professions, ethics, politics and promotions. Players choose one of five professions and move around the board earning kudos for their accomplishments. These professions include: Technology, Operations, Marketing, Accounting and Sales. If the player has enough kudos when they reach their review, they receive a promotion to the next level. The first player to reach the CEO level becomes the winner of the game. During the game, players will experience corporate politics; be challenged by questions; make management risk decisions; and learn about business tools. In addition, there is an optional team play to develop teamwork.

In his turn player rolls dice and a card is drawn where the question is asked according to dice-roll. If the answer is correct the player advances his pawn one step further.
there are also some colored barriers on the game board what need only the correct answers otherwise the pawns moves back one step.

The player who finishes first on the board is the winner.

The game contains 3300 questions and answer choices from the varied experience and experience range from pre-school children.
In his turn player rolls the die and draws a card where the question is read according to die roll. There are four possible answers for each question. Player gets the card if the answer is correct.

At the end of the game the player with the most cards is the winner.

The game contains 3300 questions and answer choices from the varied experience and experience range from pre-school children.
In his turn player rolls the die and draws a card where the question is read according to die roll. There are four possible answers for each question. Player gets the card if the answer is correct.

At the end of the game the player with the most cards is the winner.

Help to help in English.
Players are volunteers who try to help and support people who need clothes, food, medicine, work or money.
In his turn player roll the dice and move up to 4 volunteers of his team on the game board to search sponsors and needed resources. If then player is able to support one or more people/organizations he scores a point for every such act.

Player who have the most points by supporting at the end of the game is the winner.

Each player tries to complete a picture of a fish, made up of 9 tiles. Some tiles are placed openly on the table, most are facedown. In his/her turn, a player can either take an open tile and place it in his/her picture, or flip open three tiles and take one of these (if it fits into his/her picture; the tile has to be adjacent to a previously placed one). After all tiles have been seen once, a player can either take one open tile or a facedown one (that s/he has remembered from a previous turn). The first player to finish his/her picture is the winner. 
The game is made difficult by the fact that the two pictures are mirror images of each other, so it isn't always obvious which picture a tile belongs to. There are four fish pictures included, so two or four players can play.

The game consists of tiles showing postage stamps. The tiles are shuffled and placed on the table in a grid, leaving some spaces free. Each player gets a secret collector's interest tile, showing which kind of stamps s/he collects. 
In a turn, the active player picks up a tile, shows it to everyone and places it facedown in one of the free spaces in the grid. This continues until all tiles have been flipped over. In subsequent turns, a player can either swap two facedown tiles, move a facedown tile to an empty space or flip open a tile, putting it back to where it was. 
When a player thinks that there are five stamps of his/her field of interest in a row, s/he flips these open to check. If correct, points are scored. Other players get as many points as "their" tiles are in a row as well. 
The player who scored most points after a certain number of rounds is the winner.

A simple "action" game for two players. Each player controls a WWI plastic biplane via a control rod mechanism. The control rods cause the biplanes to fly circles in opposite directions. It appears that players attempt to unseat each others planes from the control rods, socring points when doing so.

The game features two biplanes molded in red and yellow, a cardboard playing surface with a WWI "Battlefield" printed on it, two plastic "tents" which serve as the base for the plane/control rod mechanism, scoring tracks and markers, control rods and decals.

Armis is a two player high-strategy board game, your objective is to capture the opponent's flag. Success is achieved by planning, implementing, and assessing various strategies and tactics given specific rules, resources, and environments.

Armis rules are detailed in the Player’s Handbook; the game has three environments: land, air, and sea; and the 17 resources are: Flag, President, Vice President, Army, Aircraft Carrier, Submarine, Jet, Helicopter, Marines, Coast Guard, Reserve, Diplomat, Religion, Child, Mover, Media, and Nuke.

Given the above, players instinctively and continuously formulate offensive and defensive situations until a winner emerges.

Armis is great exercise for the mind, and the brain.

name.value: Unser Sandmännchen: Komm mit ins Traumland

item.description:
In this game about sandman, players visit foreign countries with him: India, Hawaii or Mexico etc. 
All tiles are shuffled and placed face down on the table. In his turn player turns up a tile. If the background is dark, he can either take all face-up tiles from the table and ends his turn or he can turns up another tile, but when the sandman appears on the tile the next player starts his turn. The upturned tiles stay in place for next players. When all sandmen are turned up, the player with the most travel tiles wins.

Questions about dogs - puppies, care, breeds, diseases, dog sports, origin, education, dog owners, breeding, and dog foods.

6 question on card with 3 answer choises for each question, the question is determined rolling the dice. Depending on the version you have to collect a small plate of each color or get rid of the flakes.

Trivia game about events of this year. Several variants can be played.
There are 5 questions on the card. In his turn player rolls the dice and choose aks the question or if "6" is rolled he chooses question randomly. Who answers correctly gets the card.

Player with the most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

Objective:
be the first climbing up victory points list to the top
- moving/acting by turn -

each player throws the die, moving round the board, drafting cards (some multiple choice), finding questions for answers out the 60's - 90's, gaining victory points.

Contents:

 1 game board with two game plans
 55 quiz cards with 6600 questions and answers
 4 Betting Chips
 36 Number of chips
 1 dice
 4 game characters
 1 set of instructions

item.description:
In Town Center, players build a city – in particular, the town center. They add cubes on their personal board and try to arrange them as best as possible in order to score the most victory points. Each cube represents a different type of module. Flats, shops, offices, generators, lifts, car parks, town hall can be built and stacked during the course of the game. Each module generates influence on adjacent land and on cubes directly below or above.

Each round, players will gain two cubes of different colors through a non-random mechanism, build them on their game board, then eventually stack them in order to make towers according to the building rules. If the players have done their job well, some modules will be able to evolve, becoming bigger in three dimensions. The last phase is an income phase in which players gain money from the shops and parking lots if they are supplied with electricity.

The bigger and higher your city is, the more victory points players will have at the end of the game, which lasts ten rounds – but do not forget to provide electricity to all your flats, shops, and lifts to make them more efficient.

Town Center is the second title in designer Alban Viard's "Small City" trilogy, Card City being the first.

link.value: Town Center: Lower Manhattan / Paris La Cité – St. Louis

item.description: The friends Franz von Hahn, Johnny Mauser and Waldemar see each other through a lot of adventures. In Variant 1 a players rolls the die to determine the number of tries he has to find a certain tile, depending on what he turns up the turn stone or the player’s stone is moved. The first player to reach the finish wins. In variant 2 correct tiles are placed on the board, all players win together when all tiles are on the board and the turn stone is not over the finish. In Variant 3 the players piece is moved, then tiles are searched and depending on the result the player’s piece or the turn stone is moved. The first player to reach the finish wins the game.

name.value: The Doom That Came To Atlantic City

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

You're one of the Great Old Ones – beings of ancient and eldritch power. Cosmic forces have held you at bay for untold aeons, but at last the stars are right and your maniacal cult has called you to this benighted place. Once you regain your full powers, you will unleash your Doom upon the world!

There's only one problem: You're not alone. The other Great Old Ones are here as well, and your rivals are determined to steal your cultists and snatch victory from your flabby claws! It's a race to the ultimate finish as you crush houses, smash holes in reality, and fight to call down The Doom That Came To Atlantic City!

You and your fellow players are Great Old Ones competing to be the first to destroy the world. There are two ways to achieve this:


 Any Great Old One can win by obtaining six gates, at which point the game instantly ends. You have only five gate markers because if you open a sixth gate, you win!



 At the start of the game, each Great Old One receives a Doom card providing a shortcut to victory. If you land on one of your gates and meet the preconditions, you may attempt the action listed on your Doom. If you succeed, you win!

item.description:
Players are managers of one or more boxers by training and sending them a ring, winning advertising contracts and negotiating the profit exchanges.
There is also possible to bet to boxers You think to win.

The ranking is determined by dice the fighting with the boxing cards and boxing dice.

The game is played over an entire season, the victory decide the highest revenue.

The player must find the missing pages of the storybook in the enchanted forest again. 
In his turn player rolls and moves and looks at the plate next to the target field. If it shows desired fairy tale, You get the card and a new card is revealed. If all the fairy tales have found, the player with the most cards wins.

Players are collecting interesting themes for the next show in the series, there are 6 categories - Space, Dinosaurs, Technology, Underwater, Nature and Man. On the board theme- and action cards are randomly distributed. In his turn a player must answer a question from one of the 6 categories. If his answer is correct, he may move up to three spaces, if his answer is wrong, he moves one space. If his move ends on a space with a card, the player may turn the card over - if he can use it for one of his themes, he can take it. If it is an action card, he can use it immediately or later in the game. The player who gathers his 4 themes for the show first, wins the game..

Promotional game from BP, so naturally it is a game to play in a car. Each player gets a sheet of things to look out for and the one who has seen the most during the journey, wins.

On the reverse of the player sheets there are some picture puzzles, a maze and, bizarrely, a guide to giving mouth-to-mouth resuscitation.

Two opposing fleets of 5 ships each, one fleet being blue and the other red vie to see which fleet can capture all the ships of the other.
A die roll determines which fleet begins in Cadiz and which fleet begins in the Tortugas.
Players use a spinner to determine how far to move. That movement can be in any direction over GOLD roads or over the roads of his/her color. The winner is the player having any ships left, after all of the ships of the enemy have been captured.
Gold roads can be used by any player. Red cannot use Blue roads and vice versa. Any ship that arrives at the enemy headquarters captures all of the ships there. If there are no ships there the player gets back one of his own ships or the first ship subsequently captured afterwards. That ship begins again in his home area. To capture a ship it must be landed on by exact count. There are mines that might be landed on. These destroy ships which are permanently removed from the game

From NY Historical Museum: 
"The Game of Naval War" paper covered cardboard box top with a chromolithographed image of a naval battle with a gun deck in the foreground with crew members dying and ships in the background sinking and burning and two American ships coming to the rescue; cover inscribed, "THE/ GAME/ OF/ NAVAL WAR/ COPYRIGHT 1898/ McLOUGHLIN BROS/ NEW YORK/ COPYRIGHT 1898 BY F. D. MAHER."

Overall: 13 x 21 1/2 in. ( 33 x 54.6 cm )

name.value: Game of Discovering the North Pole
Game of a Dash for the North Pole

item.description:
This McLoughlin Brothers game comes from 1909.

The Object of the game is to see which player can first reach the North Pole and get home safely.

Each player using his/her colored marker must use that colored space indicator and must obey any directions on places he lands on.

Eventually players will reach a gold spot where all colored roads meet, this does not have to be by exact count. Once reaching that space players may use squares for the remainder of their attempt once again following any directions with an objective of landing on the square marked "North Pole"

Once there, any route can be used to return. If you land on another player piece that piece must be moved back 3 spaces or if that space is occupied to the next available vacant space.

bodyIQ - Premium is a game about the body, how it works, how to improve it and physical exercises.

Basically it a trivia game with a twist. There are 12 categories. 10 based on some of the bodys most important organs, 1 health check and 1 physical excersise, 600 questions/task all in all. Each turn the player roll the die, and moves his marker along the paths of the body. Depending on the space the player ends on, he will either get a question, a health check or a physical task to do. If he answers correct, or performs the task, he will win the card, giving him a number of years.

For younger players there is a multriple choise option.

There are three suggestend ways to end the game:
1) Play until one player reaches 100 years.
2) Play until one player collects all 12 categories.
3) Play for a certaing amount of time.
Whoever has the most points (=years) at the end of the game wins.

A game within the Dablo(t) family. Related to the Sami boardgame Dablot Prejjesne and to Dablo Daares.

Theme: Abstract game with soldiers and kings

Gameplay: Turnbased checkers type of game

Goal of the game: Either to capture the enemy king or reduce his forces so that only the king remains

Rules: All pieces move by single steps and can capture, by the short leap, in all directions. The soldier ("dårake") can only step in the three forward directions. Promotion does not occur. For the soldier, capture is mandatory. For the king ("gånneka") capture is optional. One can only capture a piece of the same rank or lower. Where the king is of higher rank than the soldier.

A piece moves to an empty adjacent point. If an adjacent point is occupied by an enemy piece, of the same rank or lower, and the point directly behind is vacant, then one may jump over it and capture it, as in checkers. Several pieces may be captured like this in a single turn. Dablo Frostviken follows the same rules. For soldiers a capture is mandatory. For the king a capture is optional.

A card game played with a standard 52-card deck and a mat that outline potential card plays. Players take turns placing cards out on the display mat, scoring melds of 3 cards as they do. On a single card play, it's possible to play two melds, with face cards acting as multipliers.

ULTRA STARFIRE is the fifth edition of the Starfire game system. Continuing improvements on the basic Starfire combat system, Ultra Starfire is comprised of two parts: the tactical combat system and the campaign system.

The tactical combat system is a fast-paced fleet-level war game of starship combat, still using the same simple combat system designed back in 1976. The campaign system is an empire-level economic war game where the player starts with an alien race on a single world and attempts to conquer the galaxy. Battles from the campaign system are played-out using the tactical system.

Ultra Starfire is a partial rewrite to Galactic Starfire, Fourth edition. Ultra Starfire was designed for completely balanced game play in a player versus player competitive environment. While it could still be used for story-based games, the appendixes and additional material was designed for shorter competitive campaigns.

Ultra Starfire was the first all-electronic product from the SDS, sold as a set of cross-linked PDF files, but still used the counters and map sets from Galactic Starfire.

Re-implements:

 Galactic Starfire

In the card game Flame War, each player takes the role of a forum admin. Starting threads, posting, flaming, maybe some trolling, and perhaps even bringing up a certain pony that might in fact be little and belong to someone you know...

Flame War is a fun and clever game about running a forum. Every card in the game represents a post made by a forum member, often directed at another member. Some are informational, some are random, and some are downright mean. The internet is a scary place for folks who like to read what other people write. Closing down threads scores you points, and the player who scores the most points when the game ends wins.

item.description:
Call to Glory, packaged in a mid-sized tin box, is a fast and fun card game in which players try to collect Japanese characters of different values. When a player has two or more cards of the same character in his hand, he can (possibly) lay these cards on the table and score them at the end of the round. If, however, an opponent lays out more cards of the same type, then characters of that type already on the table are discarded. When the game ends, players score for the types of characters they have on the table.

Call to Glory comes with two variants:


 "Imperial Tasks" in which players can fulfill specific tasks for extra points.
 "The Power of the Ninja" in which the Ninja cards become more powerful.


Unlike Crazy Chicken, Call to Glory is playable with 2 to 4 players. Drive is playable with 4 players, but does not have the two variants.

item.description:
Game consists of 10 numbered dice and two spotted dice.

In a turn, the ten numbered dice are thrown and then the two spotted dice. From the ten dice you may take any number of them that total the number rolled with the spotted dice.
i.e. you roll 9 with the spotted dice: you can now take away any combination of the numbered dice that add up to 9.
If successful, you throw again, and so on.

When you cannot take way the number rolled, the total of the remaing dice are added together and that is your score.

The player with the lowest score after an agreed number of rounds, wins.

Players take on the role of an emerging opera star, gaining education and training to get jobs and roles in hopes of becoming the next opera superstar!

Education and training are gained through drafting cards from the standard deck and putting these cards in play by "purchasing" them out of your hand. Job and Role cards are won at the end of each round as players qualify for and bid on the face up Opportunity cards.

The object of the game is to be the Diva with the most stars at the end of the game. Stars are earned by collecting Role cards and drawing Special cards.

Game description from the publisher:

Long ago, in the ancient city of the Mayan empire, nine temples were built with different stone blocks, but the blocks were all mixed up!

Luckily, great priests held the knowledge of powerful magic, and they can rebuild the towers without damaging them. Now they compete to create nine single-colored towers by exchanging the massive blocks of stone between them. If one of them can join the colored stones together, he will earn the right to decorate the tower with his own ladder. And if he can build an entire tower in a single color he will earn a special reward: His followers alone will forever greet the sun from the top of the tower!

In Maya, as one of these mighty priests, can you outwit your opponents and rerrange the stones of the nine towers?

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

In those far-off days when people had already ceased to live on the trees, but did not yet know how to make cars, the main occupation of men was hunting. Neither mighty mammoth, nor nosy ground squirrel – indeed, not any animal could escape the watchful eyes of experienced hunters.

In Jabba-Dabba-Dû!, you'll become the chief hunter of a tribe and go to the hunting grounds as the head of the mighty men. Get the most thick and tasty mammoth, and bring it to your women. But beware as your tribe in not the only one on these plains – and these frail parodies of men consider themselves hunters, too! Prove that it's not true! Leave them behind in pursuit of the prey!

Under the concept "Playing with Art", Rui Alípio Monteiro came up with Covert, a game that is based on the Rock, Scissor, Paper game. The "Thread" has been added to balance things out. Although mainly for kids, this is a great game to be played by adults alike.

The idea is to make kids become familiar with geometric shapes and colours as well as doing basic maths at the same time. 
- The Scissor wins against both the Thread and the Paper.
- The String wins against both the Rock and the Paper.
- The Paper wins against the Rock
- The Rock wins against the Scissor

So, according to the power of each object, these are worth either 1 or 2 Points. Each shape appears several times, so players will be able to make calculated guesses on what would be the best piece to play at a given time. The stakes increase if both players play the same piece simultaneously, since these will accumulate to the Victory Points.

A game to be played in little time with net to no set-up time! Check out more info here:
www.criacoesasolo.com

name.value: Richie Rich'$ Rich Man-Poor Man Card Game

item.description: This hand-management card game is a rummy variant that is themed on the Richie Rich comic book character. The deck consist of 36 cards, 2 each of 18 professions, ranging from Hobo to Skywriter to Doctor. After dealing the shuffled cards to the players, the first player draws a card from the person to her right. She then lays down all matched pairs in her hand. Play continues to the left. The last player to have a card in her hand wins.

In Magnificent Style is a solitaire game depicting the final desperate Confederate attack on 3 July 1863 at the Battle of Gettysburg, popularly known as Pickett’s Charge. As General Longstreet, you must decide how quickly to press your troops across this deadly open ground before allowing the men to regroup for another bound. But time is not on your side, and the longer your stalwart soldiers remain in this maelstrom of enemy fire.. the more dangerous it becomes, and the less likely they will arrive with the verve and numbers required to carry the day.

With only five turns in which to reach your objective and attack, how far can you push your luck? Your options are simple: Death or Glory!

Game Data:

Complexity: 3 on a 9 scale
Solitaire Suitability: 9 on a 9 scale
Scale: Each turn is approx. 10 minutes of real time

Game Components:

• One color Rules sheet
• 11" x 17" map
• 1 Player Aid sheet
• 45 double-sided 1/2" round small troop markers
• 28 double-sided 5/8" round large troop markers
• 20 double-sided 1/2" square counters

item.description: This is a simple game in which players spin A spinner to collect Colorform pieces that correspond to their player mat. The game comes with two sets of Colorforms that depict characters from the Where's Waldo Now book. The Colorforms are placed randomly on the spinner at the start of the game. Each turn, a player spins the spinner and can collect a Colorform from the quadrant of the spinner that the arrow points to provided the sticker matches their player mat. The first player to collect all four characters for their mat wins.

British target shooting game. The targets are four black children, and the aim is to knock them down with a pop-gun rifle that fires corks. The first to reach a pre-agreed total of successful hits, wins.

The game would now be widely seen as offensive, but is included here for historical interest.

Unusual word game. Each guest is given a sheet of twelve statements about words. Half will get an Oxford sheet, the other half a Cambridge sheet.

The Oxford sheet answers are all words using the letters in the word 'Oxford'. The Cambridge sheet answers are all words using the letters in the word 'Cambridge'.

After time runs out, the guest with the most right answers, wins.

Party game. 16 cards are placed around the room where they can all be seen by the guests. Each card has a rhyming clue to a place. Guests taking part write down their answers and the one with the most correct when the host calls "Time", wins.

Euromatch is a tactical sports game. The game shows how the match outcome is influenced by the tactical arrangement of your power. It is essential that the arrangement of our team is adopted to the opponent’s tactics.

The objective of the game is to outscore your opponent, playing cards on the board.

Elements of the game
1. Two decks of 15 cards (white and grey)
2. The pitch game board
3. The tube for marking the score of the 1st match (useful in a two-match game)


Euromecz jest sportowÄ… grÄ… taktycznÄ…. Gra pokazuje, jaki wpÅ‚yw na wynik meczu ma taktyczne rozmieszczenie naszych siÅ‚. WaÅ¼ne jest, aby ustawienie naszej druÅ¼yny byÅ‚o dobrane do taktyki przeciwnika.

Celem gry jest uzyskanie lepszego bilansu bramkowego w rozgrywanym dwumeczu.

name.value: The Goat in the Bow tie

item.description:
Ziege mit Fliege is a memory card game for children.

By turn, cards are placed face down on different piles.
This cards show either a colour, an animal, a piece of clothing or an activity.
4 different cards make one pile. Players have to remember this cards and make a sentence out of this cars, "A green beavers is skateboarding in a diving suit" for example.

link.value: HABA Fex: Fostering Executive Functions series

item.description:
Katzofant is a speed action card game for children.

Tha cards show 5 different animals in diefferent sizes.
Players compare the sizes of the animals on the table and in their hand and imitate the voice of the langest animal.
The fastest player may discard one of his cards.

The first player who gets rid of all his cards is the winner.

link.value: HABA Fex: Fostering Executive Functions series

name.value: Top This! A Pizza Flicking Game

item.description:
Top This! is a fun-filled, strategic board game of pizza making for 2 to 5 players. Manage your toppings and flick them skillfully to win!

Players take turns flicking wooden "pizza topping" pieces onto a pizza-like game board. Their goal is to position toppings so as to fulfill orders precisely, while managing their inventory of toppings. Players can earn tips by showing off (by yelling "Top This!" before flicking a topping) or by fulfilling two orders in one turn. The winner is the player with the most money (from orders and tips).

link.value: Games by the Game Artisans of Canada

name.value: I Am Vlad: Prince of Wallachia

item.description:
I Am Vlad: Prince Of Wallachia – an epic board game about the real life of Vlad the Impaler and about the habits, mysteries and actual facts of Wallachia and Transylvania – can be played by two, three or four players. The players begin the game from their own base and each have control over a Vlad hero as well as an Archer and a Wallachian Knight.

During the game, they try to eliminate the opposing Vlad heroes through tactical movements and attacks with their own units. Gameplay takes place on two boards: the Game Map and the Underworld Map. While the Game Map is the board on which all the interactions between players take place (including movement, battles, tactical actions, and the positioning of units and outposts), the Underworld is the area Archers and Wallachian Knights enter once they die in battle. I Am Vlad: Prince Of Wallachia has two types of battles: against enemy units and against neutral units; for both types, players use battle cards, magic cards, tokens, and an eight-sided die. Other tactical actions are made through tokens, gold coins, outposts, and so on.

link.value: I Am Vlad: Prince Of Wallachia – Bonus Pack

item.description:
From the game publisher's web site:

"RoShamBo (aka Rock Paper Scissors) is a board game that takes an age-old concept and transforms it into a game like no other on the market — ever. Ro Sham Bo is simple yet complex — an entertaining game that makes play fast, intense, and sometimes personal, but most of all fun.

It's pretty simple (but for those of you who have been living under a rock — no pun intended…) Rock beats scissors, scissors beats paper, paper beats rock. Got it so far?

Players advance toward the winner's level by rolling the dice or by winning challenges.

However, more is at stake than just winning the game (on the board) — challenges can go beyond traditional game play.

Along the way players land on spaces that call for challenges that range from moving ahead a few spaces and changing places with the winner, to being everyone's butler for the rest of the game, or doing a crazy stunt or challenge of the cardholder's choice.

"A Rollicking Game of Skill" proclaims the box. And it must have been very skilful, perhaps too skilful.

The game includes 6 wooden egg cups which are placed in the centre of the table. The players have a catapult device with which they lob the egg shaped pieces into an egg cup. At least, that is what they intend to do but it must have been devilishly difficult. The most successful player wins, but I suspect the only player to get it right wins automatically.

Mad Science The Card Game is a family friendly game played in three phases. Players must first construct a creature from bodies and parts. then they battle the Horrible Experiment created by Dr. Emil Knutberger to save the city. Finally, they fight each other, knocking off parts until only one creation remains standing.

Phase One is purely cards while Phases Two and Three also make use of a D6.

The core set works best with 2 or 3 players. Expansion sets allow for up to 6 players. There is also a Phase Two Solitary version of play.
